DOC.HEAD: $adv00
For Release in Year-End Editions
UNDATED: street shooting.
DOC.TEXT: DIANA VREELAND, flamboyant arbiter of the fashion world who edited two leading women's magazines and coined the phrase ``the beautiful people.'' Exact age unknown, but believed to be about 86. IRVING STONE, whose biographical novels of Vincent Van Gogh, Michelangelo and Sigmund Freud brought history to life for millions of readers. Age 86. JOSEPH ALSOP, longtime political columnist. Age 78.

A. BARTLETT GIAMATTI, baseball lover and former president of Yale University whose short tenure as baseball commissioner was dominated by the investigation and banishment of Pete Rose. At age 51 of a heart attack. GEORGES SIMENON, prolific writer of more than 200 novels, including 80 featuring the popular Inspector Maigret. His books were translated into 55 languages and sold more than 500 million copies worldwide, making him perhaps the most widely read author of the 20th century. Age 86. ROBERT PENN WARREN, the nation's first poet laureate, winner of three Pulitzer prizes for fiction and poetry rooted in his native South. Age 84. IRVING BERLIN, whose songs such as ``Cheek to Cheek,'' ``Easter Parade,'' ``White Christmas'' and ``God Bless America'' were the essence of American popular music. Age 101. FERDINAND E. MARCOS, ruled the Philippines for more than 20 years but became an unwanted exile after being ousted in 1986. Age 72. AUGUST A. BUSCH, JR., patriarch of the world's largest brewing dynasty and president of baseball's St. Louis Cardinals. Age 90.

GRAHAM CHAPMAN, a founding member of the zany British comedy group Monty Python's Flying Circus. At age 48 of cancer. BETTE DAVIS, two-time Oscar winner whose toughness, huge eyes and haughty cigarette-smoking style made her a Hollywood legend. Age 81. ANTHONY QUAYLE, veteran actor-director. Known to film audiences for his roles as a fighting man in such films as ``The Guns of Navarone,'' he also was honored with British knighthood as a mainstay of the classical theater. Age 76. MARY McCARTHY, critic and novelist whose ice-clear observations of politics and literature made her one of America's longtime literary stars. Age 77.

VLADIMIR HOROWITZ, titan of the keyboard who brought ``controlled thunder'' to the piano, dazzling the world for 60 years. Age 85. CHARLES BECK, comic book artist who created Captain Marvel, the superhero who came to life at the word ``Shazam.'' Age 79. CLEMENT F. HAYNESWORTH JR., whose nomination to the Supreme Court in 1969 was rejected by the Senate because of his business practices and his views on minorities. Age 77.

ALVIN AILEY, dancer and choreographer whose dynamic style introduced black American music and traditions into modern dance and helped transform it into a popular art form. At age 58 of a blood disorder. SAMMY FAIN, Oscar-winning composer whose classic love ballads included ``Love Is a Many Splendored Thing'' and ``I'll Be Seeing You.'' Age 87. JOHN PAYNE, leading man who starred in Hollywood musicals with Alice Faye and Betty Grable and in dramas such as ``Miracle on 34th Street.'' Age 77. ANDREI SAKHAROV, Soviet dissident, Nobel Peace Prize winner and brilliant scientist who built the Soviet hydrogen bomb. Risked his status as a national hero to openly challenge the government on behalf of disarmament and human rights. Age 68.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release in Year-End Editions
